awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Understanding Constraints on Floral Evolution: A Phylogenetic Approach to Comparative Anthocyanin Evolution in Ruellia (Acanthaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project combines new approaches and methods to understand evolutionary changes in flower color in a group of plants, Ruellia (Acanthaceae), with 200+ species in the Americas. The focus is on anthocyanins (the blue to red pigments that are the most important contributors of color in flowers). Cutting edge DNA sequencing approaches will be used to study the plant biochemical pathways that produce anthocyanins. These results will be placed in an evolutionary context to understand what happens when, for example, purple flowers evolve from red-flowered ancestors. The phylogeny or family tree of Ruellia will be reconstructed using novel molecular markers to be developed for this project; these markers will subsequently be useful to numerous other researchers. 

Flowers are among the most common means by which people connect to nature: floral biology has great potential to engage broad audiences in science. This research is also important because it will shed light on the anthocyanins biochemical pathway. Anthocyanins contribute to numerous plant functions (e.g., pollinator and fruit disperser attraction, UV sunscreen, herbivore defense), and have also been linked to human health benefits (e.g., anti-cancer, -viral, -inflammatory, -arteriosclerosis activity; treatments for hypertension, vision disorders). Anthocyanins are common constituents of human diets, being found in frequently consumed fruits and vegetables. This research project will add substantially to knowledge of the genetic basis of anthocyanin production and will thus have implications for human health research.

por.por_cntn:
Plant pollinator interactions are some of the most important and compelling ecological relationships in nature. NSF Award #1355138 (“Collaborative Research: Understanding Constraints on Floral Evolution: A Phylogenetic Approach to Comparative Anthocyanin Evolution in Ruellia (Acanthaceae)”) enabled the PIs to better understand plant pollinator interactions. Specifically, we studied patterns of flower color switches (evolutionary changes) in a large group of plants: the genus Ruellia (Acanthaceae). Among species of Ruellia, some are adapted to pollination by bats, hummingbirds, hawkmoths, bees, and butterflies, and flowers range from yellow to red, white, purple, blue, and pink. Our research began with the work supported by this award (part of a collaborative project) which involved conducting fieldwork in eight different tropical countries in the Western Hemisphere to observe plant-pollinator interactions and collect new museum specimens of the plants. We also  used a spectrometer device to measure and quantify flower color. We collected flowers in liquid fixative for later analysis using HPLC (High Performance Liquid Chromatography) back in the lab. This work allowed us to discover the different ways in which plants make flowers apparently of the same color (e.g., purple, pink, red). This is important because it tells us about the commonality or rarity of pollinator adaptations, and how hard or easy these floral traits are to evolve, which has conservation implications. Plants can very easily figure out adapatations to bees and hummingbirds, but adaptative solutions towards hawkmoth or bat pollination are less common.

            As part of this research, we documented numerous new populations of Ruellia living in the wild, and these are populations of plants that thousands of different animal pollinators rely on for their health and nutrition. Each of these new populations was “vouchered” meaning we collected plant samples from it and deposited these samples at worldwide museums. Here, records of the existence of these species, in time and in space, will survive for centuries, allowing researchers to know, for the long term, where a given species used to live, where it lives now, and why geographical distributions might be shifting. We are using results from this extensive fieldwork to lay the first steps for a “taxonomic revision” of the genus in the Neotropics, that is, a complete record of where all species live, what kind of environments they live in, whether they are common or rare, what their pollinators are, what their threats to existence are, and so forth. A taxonomic revision is the gold standard in biodiversity research, for it allows us to read/review a complete set of information about any group of organisms. At present, we are additionally preparing a new classification system for all Neotropical Ruellia.

            This research has impacted numerous new scholars and students of biology. We have established new colleagues in numerous countries as well as built upon existing collegial relationships. Some of these students are now coming to study in our labs in the United States, and we (the PIs) serve on their graduate committees. We are also launching new collaborative projects with researchers in these many different countries.

            On the whole, this project beneffited both the scientific community and education, through targeted research on species diversification, flower color evolution, and taxonomy of a large and important lineage of Neotropical plants – the genus Ruellia.
